@guozhangwang @mjsax updated per comments and discussion on slack. 

Specifically, now we'll only rebuild the topology under two conditions

1. The topics passed into `StreamPartitionAssignor.subscription` don't exactly match what the current `TopologyBuilder.subscriptionUpdates` contains
2. Topics passed into `StreamPartitionAssignor.onAssign` have newly discovered topics from `ConsumerCoordinator.onJoinComplete`
retest this please

Regarding the general issue that it may get exposed: I think the root cause is in `CoordinatorResponseHandler#onFailure()` we only mark the coordinator as dead but do not do anything else; for example for `syncGroupRequest`, and then in its caller `joinGroupIfNeeded()`, we do not check the `DisconnectException` again, and the while condition `needRejoin() || rejoinIncomplete()` will also pass although the actual state is:

1. `state = MemberState.UNJOINED`.
2. `coordinator = null`.
3. `rejoinNeeded = false`.
4. `joinFuture = null`.

I think we should check all four variables above in the while condition instead.
retest this please

@junrao I actually think it helps to leave open the _option_ of directly producing to internal topics. While it is true that a user could send an `OffsetCommitRequest`, we have in the past also used the facility to emit tombstones. It also allows manually emitting group state (should you wish to do that) into the topic. So in short, IMO I don't think this backdoor should be removed.

Good catch. I wonder if we are setting `rejoinNeeded` to false too early. Perhaps that should only come after the `SyncGroup` returns?
Thanks @ewencp! Comments have been addressed and the PR is rebased.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk7-scala2.11/4707/
Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.11).

I've been thinking about a couple different options for the problem of epoch wrap-around since the current solution leaves a bit to be desired. 

1. Epochs do not wrap-around. If you reach the limit, you must get a new transactionalId. We can probably make the clear with an EPOCH_OVERFLOW error in InitProducerId. The nice thing about this approach is that it does not risk violating correctness.
2. We could pass through some additional information from the TC when the epoch is generated. For example, we could return the coordinator epoch. The producer could then pass that through in the ProduceRequest and we could use it to detect when an epoch has legitimately wrapped around. This is probably a bit more work than we can get away with this late in the game.

I think I'm actually leaning toward the first option as opposed to the current patch, which will be difficult to explain to users. In the next release, we can try to provide a more graceful way to handle the problem such as perhaps the second option. I think we expect that this will be pretty rare in practice anyway.

Thoughts?

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk7-scala2.11/4708/
Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.11).

I think option 1 seems reasonable for this release. It would be surprising if someone runs into that before the subsequent release in 4 months (where we should try to provide an easy to understand solution). It's worth noting that we'd still have the sequence wrap around solution for this release.

@ijuma Not actually sure why this wasn't running before, but it's pretty obvious now that we have a`jenkins.sh` script that doesn't invoke the right targets... Previous issues with `.git` don't seem relevant since we must be running in the root repo directory for the jenkins scripts to work, but we'll see based on the jenkins output from this test.

Looks like this can be backported to 0.10.2 and higher since that's when the `jenkins.sh` script was introduced.
(the script was introduced during the 0.11.0.0 cycle, but we backported it to 0.10.2.0 as well)
Oops, KAFKA-4459 is exactly what I meant and is in the branch name, just messed it up during commit. Fixed. Seems like we're good as long as the rat checks show up in the Jenkins builds.
